content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Mercy Ships, founded in 1978, has provided services in over 70 countries valued at $1.3 billion, treating 2.56 million beneficiaries. They operate the Africa Mercy, the world's largest private hospital ship with 5 operating rooms and space for 82 patients. The volunteer crew includes surgeons, nurses, doctors, and other professionals, performing over 82,000 life-changing operations. Mercy Ships has provided various medical services including dental treatments, training local professionals, teaching basic health care to over 198,000 people, and completing over 1,100 infrastructure projects to improve local health care delivery systems. Mercy Ships has over 1,600 volunteers annually, with 900 serving in Africa. The Africa Mercy has had over 4,900 crew members from 74 countries since 2007, completing over 589 port visits in 73 nations. Mercy Ships has had four hospital ships serving in various countries including Canada, China, Congo Brazzaville, Colombia, Cuba, and many others. Mercy Ships has operated several hospital ships in different regions, including Africa, Guatemala, the Caribbean, Central and South America. The ships varied in size and crew capacity, with missions focused on providing medical assistance to those in need. Mercy Ships operated hospital ships in various regions, including Africa, Guatemala, the Caribbean, Central, and South America. The Island Mercy was redeployed to the South Pacific in 1994 and served until 2001. Currently, Mercy Ships is building a new hospital ship for Africa with delivery expected in 2018, focusing on healthcare training and safe surgery globally. They have hosted Presidents and heads of state onboard their ships. Mercy Ships has received endorsements from various world leaders and heads of state for providing free healthcare on their hospital ships. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for the presentation of a gold medal to Don and Deyon Stephens, Founders of Mercy Ships. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems. Duplicates in bronze may be sold by the Secretary. The medals struck under this Act are national medals and considered numismatic items under title 31, United States Code.
